bibl.title: Military Orders for Aristides Agramonte, July 17, 1900

div1.p: Special Orders #69 orders Agramonte to Pinar del Rio to investigate cases of pernicious fever. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Military Orders for Aristides Agramonte, July 17, 1900
div1.p:
NOTED: RETURNS, A. G. O.,
9

Adjutant General's
OFFICE.
JUL 28 1900
ROLLS DIVISION.
[unclear]

ORDERS, BOOKS, BLANKS & D.C. DIV.
A. G. O.
RECD. JUL 26 1900
Agramonte

FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Vol 175 A 1900

SPECIAL ORDERS, }
No. 112. }

HEADQUARTERS DIVISION OF CUBA,
Havana, July 17, 1900.

1. Acting Assistant Surgeon A. Agramonte, U. S. Army,
will proceed without delay from this city to Pinar del Río
Barracks, Pinar del Río, Cuba, reporting upon arrival to
the commanding officer, for the purpose of examining into
the exact nature of certain cases of pernicious fever reported
to have occurred at said post, on completion of which duty
he will rejoin his proper station.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

2. The following named enlisted men of the Signal Corps,
U. S. Army, now on duty in this city and Quemados, Cuba,
will proceed by the first available transport to New York
City, New York, thence to Fort Myer, Virginia, reporting
upon arrival to the commanding officer for duty:
Sergeant Daniel Southwell, in charge,
Sergeant Arthur P. McCarthy,
Sergeant Charles W. Brown,
Private James Murphy,
Private Matthew Thompson,
Private Thomas M. Carter,
Private James R. Collins,
Private C. W. Owens.

The Quartermaster's Department will furnish the neces-
sary transportation, and the Subsistence Department travel
rations for two (2) days.
The travel enjoined is necessary for the public service.

BY COMMAND OF MAJOR GENERAL WOOD:
H. L. SCOTT,
Acting Adjutant General.
